review.title: Parameterized Complexity Results for Exact Bayesian Network Structure Learning
review.abstract: Bayesian network structure learning is the notoriously difficult problem of discovering a Bayesian network that optimally represents a given set of training data. In this paper we study the computational worst-case complexity of exact Bayesian network structure learning under graph theoretic restrictions on the (directed) super-structure. The super-structure is an undirected graph that contains as subgraphs the skeletons of solution networks. We introduce the directed super-structure as a natural generalization of its undirected counterpart. Our results apply to several variants of score-based Bayesian network structure learning where the score of a network decomposes into local scores of its nodes. Results: We show that exact Bayesian network structure learning can be carried out in non-uniform polynomial time if the super-structure has bounded treewidth, and in linear time if in addition the super-structure has bounded maximum degree. Furthermore, we show that if the directed super-structure is acyclic, then exact Bayesian network structure learning can be carried out in quadratic time. We complement these positive results with a number of hardness results. We show that both restrictions (treewidth and degree) are essential and cannot be dropped without loosing uniform polynomial time tractability (subject to a complexity-theoretic assumption). Similarly, exact Bayesian network structure learning remains NP-hard for "almost acyclic" directed super-structures. Furthermore, we show that the restrictions remain essential if we do not search for a globally optimal network but aim to improve a given network by means of at most k arc additions, arc deletions, or arc reversals (k-neighborhood local search).

sections.text: Results: We show that exact Bayesian network structure learning can be performed in unequal polynomial time when the superstructure has a limited tree width, and in linear time when the superstructure also has a maximum degree. Furthermore, we show that exact Bayesian network structure learning can be performed in square time when the directed superstructure is acyclic. We supplement these positive results with a series of hardness results. We show that both constraints (tree width and degree) are indispensable and cannot be removed without losing the uniform polynomic time traceability (subject to a complexity theory assumption). Likewise, exact Bayesian network structure learning remains essential for "almost acyclic" directed superstructures NP-hard. Furthermore, we show that the constraints remain indispensable if we are not looking for a globally optimal network, but rather seek a circular arc-shaped network at most.

sections.heading: 1.1 Results
sections.text: In this section we give a brief overview of our results.

sections.heading: 1.1.1 Exact BNSL Using the Super-structure
sections.text: In the first part of our thesis, we examine the worst-case complexity of Exact BNSL under graphical constraints of the superstructure. One of the most prominent constraints of the superstructure we are considering is Treewidth. Treewidth is an important and widely used parameter that measures the similarity of a diagram to a tree (Bodlaender, 1993, 1997, 2005; Greco & Scarcello, 2010). Similar to trees, many otherwise intractable problems become apparent on charts of limited Treewidth. More importantly, Treewidth has already been successfully applied in the context of Bayesian Reasoning (Darwiche, 2001; Dechter, 1999; Kwisthout, Bodlaender, & van der Gaag, 2010). It therefore seems only natural to apply Treewidth to (Exact) BNSL (Exact).

sections.heading: 1.1.2 Local Search BNSL Using the Super-structure
sections.text: A popular heuristic for BNSL is the so-called hill-climbing method, or local search. In particular, a highly competitive algorithm for learning large Bayesian networks (MMHC) uses local search to find an optimal solution within a previously constructed superstructure (Tsamardinos et al., 2006). We are investigating the complexity of the worst-case of a well-known generalization of the local search, the k-Neighborhood Local Search (or k-Local Search for short). In this variant of the local search, it is allowed to modify not one, but up to k-arcs in each step of the search. Therefore, one can compensate for speed and accuracy by adapting to k. However, since the k-local search space is of order nO (k), the use of k-local search is particularly desirable for problems where runtime increases only slightly with respect to k. sections.text: We introduce the directed superstructure as a more expressive way to limit the search space of solutions, i.e. once the directed superstructure is fixed, we limit our search to solutions whose networks are contained in the directed superstructure. Here, too, we examine the complexity of the exact BNSL in relation to certain constraints of the directed superstructure and obtain the following result. However, we show that this is not the case. (8) Exact BNSL is NP-hard for directed superstructures that can be made acyclic by deleting a node. sections.heading: 1.2 Related Work
sections.text: In this section we present relevant work on BNSL. Further related work can be found in the corresponding sections, i.e. we present related work on parameterized complexity in Section 2.2, related work on tree width and decomposition in Section 2.3 and 3.1, and in Section 7 we present related work on local search in the k neighborhood.

sections.heading: 1.2.1 Algorithms for Exact BNSL
sections.text: These can be divided into three groups: (A) exact algorithms that do not apply constraints (Parviainen & Koivisto, 2010; Koivisto, 2006; Yuan, Malone, & Wu, 2011; Ott, Imoto, & Miyano, 2004; Silander & Myllyma ¿ki, 2006; Yuan & al., 2011), (B) exact algorithms that use constraints on generation or target distribution (Pieter et al., 2006; Chechetka & Guestrin, 2007; Friedman, Nachman, & Pe'er, 1999; Chow & Liu, 1968; Gaspers, Koivisto et al., 2012), and (C) exact algorithms that apply constraints on the undirected superstructure (Friedman et al., 1999; Kojima, Perrier, & Miyano, 2010), the algorithms that fall into group (C), algorithms that do not apply constraints on the undirected superstructure, because they are unique structures.

sections.heading: 1.2.2 Hardness Results for Exact BNSL
sections.text: There are also a number of hardness results for BNSL under constraints of the resulting Bayesian network. Specifically, BNSL remains NP-hard if the degree of the resulting Bayesian network is limited to 2 (Chickering, 1996), and if the resulting Bayesian network is a polytree (Dasgupta, 1999) or a directed path (Meek, 2001). To our knowledge, however, no negative results have been obtained for BNSL under constraints of (directed) superstructure.

sections.heading: 1.3 Organization and Prior Work
sections.text: This paper is organized as follows: In Section 2 we present the basic concepts and terms we use throughout the paper; in Section 3 we present the main objective of our study (BNSL); Section 4 shows how we use a dynamic programming algorithm on a tree decomposition to show results (1) and (2); in Section 5 we provide a more refined complexity analysis of our algorithm; in Section 6 we show the complexity limits for exact BNSL based on a superstructure, i.e. we obtain results (3) and (4); we introduce k-Local Search BNSL in Section 7, where we specify results (5) and (6); we introduce the directed superstructure in Section 8 and show results (7) and (8); and in Section 9 we conclude with an appendix containing the evidence of some technical assertions. A preliminary and abridged version of this paper appeared in the procedures of UAI 2010. Apart from providing a higher level of results, we conclude in Section 9 (7) and (8).

sections.heading: 2.2 Parameterized Complexity
sections.text: Parametrized complexity provides a theoretical framework for distinguishing between uniform and non-uniform problems of polynomial time traceability in relation to a parameter. It was introduced and pioneered by Downey and Fellows (1999) and is receiving increasing interest, reflected in the recent publication of two further monographs (Flum & Grohe, 2006; Niedermeier, 2006) and hundreds of research papers (see references in the above monographs). In 2008, the Computer Journal devoted two specific problems to parametrized complexity in order to make the key methods and ideas known to a wide range of computer scientists (Downey, Fellows, & Langston, 2008). One instance of a parametrized problem is a pair (I, k) where I am the main part and k is the parameter; the latter is usually a non-negative integer.

sections.text: In introducing our algorithm in Section 4, we focused on a comprehensive assessment of its complexity. In this section, we provide a finer-grained analysis of its runtime. In the following, we assume that N is a series of nodes, f is a local score function on N, and (T, c, r) is a nice tree decomposition of Sf of width at most w. We can improve the runtime of our algorithm by keeping records for each node in tree decomposition in a fixed order. We can improve the time needed on a common tree decomposition node from O (w + 1) f) to O (w + 1f) at no additional cost to sort. We achieve this by generating new records in an orderly manner and tracking the sequence in which the records are stored.

sections.heading: 8. The Directed Super-structure
sections.text: In the previous sections, we considered the problem of Exact BNSL and k-Local Search BNSL solvable if the structure of the undirected superstructure is limited. However, it is a natural question whether the additional information contained in the directed superstructure can be used to find new structural constraints under which Exact BNSL becomes solvable if the input is given in the Ararity c representation (Teyssier & Koller, 2005). Fixing an order of variables in a BN corresponds to restricting the search space to acyclic-directed superstructures. Our first observation of this section is that Exact BNSL is solvable in polynomial representation.

sections.heading: 9. Conclusion
sections.text: We have studied the computational complexity of Bayesian Structure Learning (BNSL) under various constraints of the (directed) superstructure, taking into account both Exact BNSL and k-Local Search BNSL. We have achieved positive as well as negative results for the theoretical worst-case complexities of the problems. Our main positive result is that Exact BNSL is linear-time tractable when the superstructure has a limited tree width and a limited maximum degree. Our results show which combinations of structural constraints make the problems tractable and which constraints cannot be removed without losing tractability. Considering various combinations of constraints in a systematic way gives us a more comprehensive picture of the complexity landscape (see table in Section 1).

Important and widely used algorithms for BNSL are based on local search methods (Heckerman, Geiger, & Chickering, 1995). Usually the local search algorithm tries to improve the score of a given dag by transforming it into a new dag by adding, deleting, or reversing one arc at a time (in symbols: add, del, and rev, respectively). The main obstacle for local search methods is the danger of getting stuck at a poor local optimum. A possibility for decreasing this danger is to perform k > 1 elementary changes in one step, known as kNeighborhood Local Search or k-Local Search for short. For BNSL, when we try to improve the score of a dag on n nodes, the k-local search space is of order nO(k). Therefore, if carried out by brute-force, k-local search is too costly even for small values of k. It is therefore not surprising that most practical local search algorithms for BNSL consider 1-neighborhoods only. The study of the parameterized complexity of k-local search was initiated by Fellows (2003). To date a collection of positive and negative results on the parameterized complexity of k-local search for various combinatorial optimization problems are known.

metadata.abstractText: Bayesian network structure learning is the notoriously difficult problem of discovering a Bayesian network that optimally represents a given set of training data. In this paper we study the computational worst-case complexity of exact Bayesian network structure learning under graph theoretic restrictions on the (directed) super-structure. The super-structure is an undirected graph that contains as subgraphs the skeletons of solution networks. We introduce the directed super-structure as a natural generalization of its undirected counterpart. Our results apply to several variants of score-based Bayesian network structure learning where the score of a network decomposes into local scores of its nodes. Results: We show that exact Bayesian network structure learning can be carried out in non-uniform polynomial time if the super-structure has bounded treewidth, and in linear time if in addition the super-structure has bounded maximum degree. Furthermore, we show that if the directed super-structure is acyclic, then exact Bayesian network structure learning can be carried out in quadratic time. We complement these positive results with a number of hardness results. We show that both restrictions (treewidth and degree) are essential and cannot be dropped without loosing uniform polynomial time tractability (subject to a complexity-theoretic assumption). Similarly, exact Bayesian network structure learning remains NP-hard for “almost acyclic” directed super-structures. Furthermore, we show that the restrictions remain essential if we do not search for a globally optimal network but aim to improve a given network by means of at most k arc additions, arc deletions, or arc reversals (k-neighborhood local search).
